contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox TV channel | name = Yle Fem | logofile = Yle Fem logo.svg | logosize = 200px | launch = 27 August 2001 | closed date = | picture format = 16:9 | owner = [[Yle]] | slogan = | country = {{flag|Finland}} | language = [[Swedish language|Swedish]] | broadcast area = [[Finland]] | headquarters = | former names = YLE FST <br/> <small>(1988 - August 2006)</small><br/>YLE FST5 <br/> <small>(August 2006 - March 2012)</small> | replaced names = | share = 1.6% | share as of = 2011 | share source = <ref>{{cite web|title=Results From The TV Audience Measurement|url=http://www.finnpanel.fi/en/tulokset/tv/vuosi/share/viimeisin/|publisher=Finnpanel|accessdate=14 July 2012}}</ref> | sister names = [[Yle TV1]]<br />[[Yle TV2]]<br />[[Yle Teema]]<br />[[Yle HD]] | timeshift names = | web = [http://svenska.yle.fi/fem/ svenska.yle.fi/fem] | terr serv 1 = Digital | terr chan 1 = Channel 5 | sat serv 1 = [[Thor 3]] | sat chan 1 = 12.054 GHz H | cable serv 1 = [[Elisa Oyj|Elisa]] | cable chan 1 = Channel 5 | cable serv 2 = [[DNA Oy|DNA]] | cable chan 2 = Channel 5 | cable serv 3 = Welho | cable chan 3 = Channel 5 }} '''Yle Fem''' (''Yle Five'') is [[Yle]]'s [[Finland-Swedish]] national television channel, providing television programmes in the [[Swedish language]] in [[Finland]]. It is a public-service channel principally intended for Finland's Swedish-speaking minority. Creating understanding over the language and culture border is also one of the channel's recognized objectives.<ref>[http://translate.google.co.uk/translate?u=http%3A%2F%2Fsvenska.yle.fi%2Ffst5%2Finfo.php&sl=sv&tl=en&hl=&ie=UTF-8 Description on the channel's web site] (translation)</ref> Yle Fem was previously known as YLE FST5<ref>[http://svenska.yle.fi/author.php?id=14324 YLE FST5 changes name to Yle Fem]</ref> ('''Finlands Svenska Television''', literally ''"Finland's Swedish Television"'') but the name was changed because the viewers thought the name was only a combination of letters (Fem is Swedish for five.). Initially, Finlands Svenska Television's output was formerly included in the programming of Yle's two main television channels, [[Yle TV1|TV1]] and [[Yle TV2|TV2]]. However, since 1 September 2007, all of Yle's Swedish-language television programmes are now broadcast exclusively on digital channel FST5. ==TV programmes== [[Image:Fst5logo.png|rught|thumb|Old logo, used 2007-2012]] [[Image:FST Finnish Swedish-language television logo.png|right|thumb|Old logo, used until 2007]] *''[[360 grader]]'' *''[[Bettina S.]]'' *''[[Buu-klubben]]'' *''[[D-Dax]]'' *''[[Enigma (game show)|Enigma]]'' *''[[Falkenswärds möbler]]'' *''[[Fribby]]'' *''[[Idrottsbiten]]'' *''[[JOX]]'' *''[[Kortnytt]]'' *''[[Melodifestivalen]]'' *''[[Neon (television)|Neon]]'' *''[[Nordiska videolistan]]'' *''[[Närbild Svenskfinland]]'' *''[[OBS (television)|OBS]]'' *''[[Oppåner å hitådit]]'' *''[[Pussel]]'' *''[[Ratatosk (disambiguation)|Ratatosk]]'' *''[[Scen]]'' *''[[Schlager på lager]]'' *''[[Sicsac]]'' *''[[Solarplexus]]'' *''Solo *''[[Sportnytt]] *''Spotlight'' *''[[Strömsö]]'' *''[[TV-Nytt]]'' *''[[Tärningen]]'' *''[[Vad gör Petra?]]'' *''[[X-tra]]'' {{Expand list|date=August 2008}} ==See also== *[[List of Finnish television channels]] == References == <references/> == External links == *[http://svenska.yle.fi/fem/ Yle Fem] - Official site {{YLE}} {{Finnish television channels}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Yle Fem}} [[Category:Television stations in Finland]] [[Category:Publicly funded broadcasters]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2001]]
